entry.title: Leetcode#146.Â LRU Cache
entry.content:
Problem

Design a data structure that follows the constraints of aÂ Least Recently Used (LRU) cache.

Implement theÂ LRUCacheÂ class:

  • LRUCache(int capacity)Â Initialize the LRU cache withÂ positiveÂ sizeÂ capacity.
  • int get(int key)Â Return the value of theÂ keyÂ if the key exists, otherwise returnÂ 1.
  • void put(int key, int value)Â Update the value of theÂ keyÂ if theÂ keyÂ exists. Otherwise, add theÂ key-valueÂ pair to the cache. If the number of keys exceeds theÂ capacityÂ from this operation,Â evictÂ the least recently used key.

The functionsÂ getÂ andÂ putÂ must each run inÂ O(1)Â average time complexity.

Example 1:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= capacity <= 3000
  • 0 <= key <= 10^4
  • 0 <= value <= 10^5

entry.title: Leetcode#224.Â Basic Calculator
entry.content:
Problem

Given a stringÂ sÂ representing a valid expression, implement a basic calculator to evaluate it, and returnÂ the result of the evaluation.

Note:Â You areÂ notÂ allowed to use any built-in function which evaluates strings as mathematical expressions, such asÂ eval().

Example 1:

Example 2:

Example 3:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= s.length <= 3 * 10^5
  • sÂ consists of digits,Â '+',Â '-',Â '(',Â ')', andÂ ' '.
  • sÂ represents a valid expression.
  • '+'Â isÂ notÂ used as a unary operation (i.e.,Â "+1"Â andÂ "+(2 + 3)"Â is invalid).
  • '-'Â could be used as a unary operation (i.e.,Â "-1"Â andÂ "-(2 + 3)"Â is valid).
  • There will be no two consecutive operators in the input.

entry.title: Leetcode#427.Â Construct Quad Tree
entry.content:
Problem

Given aÂ n * nÂ matrixÂ gridÂ ofÂ 0'sÂ andÂ 1'sÂ only. We want to representÂ gridÂ with a Quad-Tree.

ReturnÂ the root of the Quad-Tree representingÂ grid.

A Quad-Tree is a tree data structure in which each internal node has exactly four children. Besides, each node has two attributes:

  • val: True if the node represents a grid of 1â€™s or False if the node represents a grid of 0â€™s. Notice that you can assign theÂ valÂ to True or False whenÂ isLeafÂ is False, and both are accepted in the answer.
  • isLeaf: True if the node is a leaf node on the tree or False if the node has four children.

We can construct a Quad-Tree from a two-dimensional area using the following steps:

  1. If the current grid has the same value (i.e allÂ 1'sÂ or allÂ 0's) setÂ isLeafÂ True and setÂ valÂ to the value of the grid and set the four children to Null and stop.
  2. If the current grid has different values, setÂ isLeafÂ to False and setÂ valÂ to any value and divide the current grid into four sub-grids as shown in the photo.
  3. Recurse for each of the children with the proper sub-grid.

If you want to know more about the Quad-Tree, you can refer to theÂ wiki.

Quad-Tree format:

You donâ€™t need to read this section for solving the problem. This is only if you want to understand the output format here. The output represents the serialized format of a Quad-Tree using level order traversal, whereÂ nullÂ signifies a path terminator where no node exists below.

It is very similar to the serialization of the binary tree. The only difference is that the node is represented as a listÂ [isLeaf, val].

If the value ofÂ isLeafÂ orÂ valÂ is True we represent it asÂ 1Â in the listÂ [isLeaf, val]Â and if the value ofÂ isLeafÂ orÂ valÂ is False we represent it asÂ 0.

Example 1:

Example 2:

entry.title: Leetcode#87.Â Scramble String
entry.content:
Problem

We can scramble a string s to get a string t using the following algorithm:

  1. If the length of the string is 1, stop.
  2. If the length of the string is > 1, do the following:
    • Split the string into two non-empty substrings at a random index, i.e., if the string isÂ s, divide it toÂ xÂ andÂ yÂ whereÂ s = x + y.
    • RandomlyÂ decide to swap the two substrings or to keep them in the same order. i.e., after this step,Â sÂ may becomeÂ s = x + yÂ orÂ s = y + x.
    • Apply step 1 recursively on each of the two substringsÂ xÂ andÂ y.

entry.title: Leetcode#202.Â Happy Number
entry.content:
Problem

Write an algorithm to determine if a numberÂ nÂ is happy.

AÂ happy numberÂ is a number defined by the following process:

  • Starting with any positive integer, replace the number by the sum of the squares of its digits.
  • Repeat the process until the number equals 1 (where it will stay), or itÂ loops endlessly in a cycleÂ which does not include 1.
  • Those numbers for which this processÂ ends in 1Â are happy.

ReturnÂ trueÂ ifÂ nÂ is a happy number, andÂ falseÂ if not.

Example 2:

Constraints:
